description: For what this place is, you couldn't possibly ask for any more. The food is hot, it's fresh, the sauces are tasty, it's reasonably priced. I've been several times - the only time I was disappointed was when I got there shortly before closing and they had limited options. I love the eggplant, i love the orange chicken, or Gen'l Tsao's or whatever they have. I like the fried crispy rolls and "dim sum" type things. The veggies are good - not overcooked or soggy like many buffets. And I almost always get one of those sesame balls for dessert.
author: Richard M.

description:
This place happened to be opened late so I stopped by for a quick bite. They serve food by the weight; you grab a plate and put whatever items you like, and at the end they weight it and you pay accordingly.

Unfortunately the food was not very good, and by the time I had gotten to eat it, it looked like it had been sitting outside for a long time. There were various Chinese take-out like items, along with some dim sum and other bits and pieces, but the sad part is that nothing tasted all that good.

The noodles had been all broken up, the curry was too salty, the food in general was lukewarm, the whole experience overall was just disappointing.

I don't think I will be back, unless I am only a little hungry and want a quick bite, but even though I'd rather walk down to Sam Wo and they are open late and have slightly better food.
author: Tyler T.

description:
China Fun Express is a pay-by-the-pound Chinese buffet on Kearny in FiDi. I've been here a couple of times just before their closing time to find only leftovers in the trays. I'm not sure at what point they stop refilling the trays but around 8 pm you will be greeted by half empty containers. I've seen people walk-in, have a look and then walk right out seeing the sorry state of affairs, but without many options in the area, at the time, I get what looks like the freshest from the lot.

It is your standard Chinese buffet so you have your standard Chinese Chicken, Beef and Pork dishes along with fried rice, noodles and also some dim-sum options. The food is very average and nothing to write home about. Fried rice and noodles were also not bad. Beef was not overly chewy. Even the leftovers at closing time are very eatable. Keep your expectations low and you will not be disappointed.

Pricewise they are $6.68 per pound. A decent lunch plate would be about 2-2.5 lbs which will run you around $15 with tax. This is the cheapest option that you will find in FiDi. Lee's is $8.75/lb and Chez Falayala and the like are $11+/lb. Average food at reasonable costs (for the area) is how I'd sum up.
author: Ahmad J.

description: I oeft this place not knowing wtf had happened. It was like stepping out of a jarring nightmare. I don't lile to leave negative reviews but this particular experience was so bad that I feel the need to inform others. My family and I had just come back from the museum and were atarving. We typed Asian food into google maps and came across this restaraunt. It seemed convenient and appealing so we went in. The items available were extremely limited - just a few old pans of food under heat lamps in the corner. The store itself was dead - no music, no vibes, no ambience, zero attractive qualities. After picking through the pans of food (one of the workers kept forcing herself into our space to wipe and clean under us as we were getting our food despite the fact that we were being cautious and leaving no mess) for things that kinda looked good, we went to the register and found out that your plate was priced by WEIGHT. Whatever, it's the restaraunt's discretion but I really would have liked to be warned beforehand. We pay, take the plates of food, go upstairs, and proceed to attempt to choke down some of the most AWFUL restaraunt food we have ever had. Not even the two ravenous middle school boys with us could eat it. Add to that, the sound of RETCHING coming from the street under the window and the odd musty smell that permeated the restauraunt. Honestly, I hate to say this, but the meal put a real damper on an otherwise fun day. Just the thought of the stale food and nauseating smell makes me want to  retch months later. The only reason that we didn't ask for a refund was because we were that hungry.
author: Jamilah P.

description: This place is as bad as you can get it you are looking for fresh or warm chinese food. You would have better luck at your local grocery store that has a chinese hot food section. Service...what service?! The place is not the dirtiest but still...don't waste your time. We paid $27.59 for 2 plates of cold food & a water bottle. One of the worst places I've been to.
author: Michelle F.

description:
When you want cheap comforting chinese take out in FiDi, this is a great option. I came for a late lunch and found the food to still be pretty fresh--it's all by weight and I filled up a small square container with a little bit of everything--chicken wings (which was my initial craving), some ho fun noodles, broccoli, sesame chicken (no judge), and a couple of other little things. When it rang up (which, it was a good amount of food stuffed in the container!) It was about $6. The lady at the register offered me soup since I reached the $5 minimum--nice! I decided to be weird and mix the hot and sour with the Egg Drop (what can I say, I find HS soup too sour and ED too sweet). 

That stuff really hit the spot. Pretty good price for a little bit of all the goods ;) Way better than ordering a ton of food you can't finish from any other take out place that has standard orders! compared to a place like Lee's, I'd say the variety here is better for the chinese-styled fare but I'd rather go to Lees for sandwiches or salads, or for an all around, lil' of everything option. 

I'd love to see more places offer a pay per pound option, it's great for those of us who just like to taste. I'll be back at my next craving!
author: Nerissa C.

description: Pretty marginal. For food by the pound, this place is pretty ruff. Pretty much the only good thing about the place is that it's low cost $7/pound and it's open relatively late. Otherwise, take a walk over to Chinatown 5 minutes away.
author: Leung T.

description:
You can't hold this place to the same standard to which you hold Hakkasan or Crystal Jade.

For the price and the setup, it's fantastic. I've come at lunch hour and everything is fresh and steaming hot. Prices are reasonable - like everyone else says, you get more value if you load up on things other than rice. It's obviously not the best quality food in the world but I would come back again and again.

The staff are nice and helpful and accommodating if you're nice to them. Some of them don't speak english very well, so that might be a barrier to communication to some. :( 

I came in with the intention of getting a small, cheap meal (an alternative to the $15 salads everywhere else), got the small square container and packed it. Rice on the bottom, and lots of broccoli and some meat and tofu sides on top. Full but not exploding/overflowing and it came out to be ~2lbs (~$13). Woops. I had leftovers to take home after lunch, though! Be careful to not overestimate your portions :) 

Would come here again and again and again!
author: Veronica H.

description: I stopped by here after work one day and I won't make that mistake again. The food wasn't very good at all. It was super dry and looked as if it had been sitting out for hours. I picked around on my plate and tried to make it work because I was hungry, but I eventually just gave up. I won't return.
author: Toni H.

description:
I ran here after a long day of traveling for work and found this place. Everything else in the area was closed or super crowded. I just wanted some place I could run in and grab food with as little social interaction as possible.

The hot and sour is good. Not as sour as I'd like it, but it hit the spot. I didn't realize the soup was free, so that was a bonus. I went in at 8:50pm and according to yelp, they should be closed at this time, but they were still open. The food all looks good. Definitely not 5 star restaurant, but that wasn't what I was on a mission for. I'm wasn't super well labeled so some of the food I'm about to eat will be a surprise! :-) I would go here again if I needed something fast and filling.
author: Nichole C.

description:
Exactly like what you expect: a Chinese buffet.

This is a sort of crummy little Chinese buffet on Kearny that provides ~$7 per pound Chinese food.  It's clean in that wiped-over sort of way, fairly popular, and pretty unpretentious - it's a dive.

The food here is... tolerable.  For people looking at get food as quickly as possible (like me, at the time), this place works: your stomach will be filled.  The food is greasy and simple, which has its merits at certain points.  With that said, this is no upscale Chinatown cuisine or anything - this is a hair lower than Panda Express at best.
author: Kirk S.

description: Literally go here everyday. Go during peak time, that's when it's hot and lots of turnaround. MUST GET the sesame chicken, China fun shrimp. It's like crack. I'm so addicted to it I eat it daily!!! Their Singapore noodles are great too. Honestly, for the price, there's a great variety and they're all tasty! Most of all, they are all so friendly. They always say hello, and have a good day, and make you feel welcome!! That is what keeps me coming back.
author: Maggie J.

description: This place is filthy. I saw a small roach roaming around the floor. I'm surprised the health dept haven't checked on this place. The food isn't that great either. It doesn't look fresh. Good thing their credit card terminal declined my bank card. I lost my appetite after seeing that roach. Who knows what other bugs might be lurking at this place.
author: Lawrence F.

description: Good food, easy in and out, well priced. No complaints. Nothing fancy but steady stream of all types of people
author: mj r.

description:
What's so fun about China Fun Express? Are we having fun yet? Perhaps it brings joy to the indiscriminate FiDi working drone who would prefer working in the 'burbs where he or she could gorge at a Panda Express. At least that's who I'm guessing is the target customer here. Otherwise I'm not sure why this Chinese cafeteria continues to survive amid the more dietetically conscious selections on Kearny. I don't know what prompted me to come here, but I have noticed I've been to the dungeon, I mean the International Food Court, a couple of times recently for new places that opened. Perhaps it's a bad trend I need to stop. Actually there's no perhaps about it. I need to stop feeding my curiosity about Asian fast food spots.

Because if it quacked like a duck, it probably ended up here in the warming trays in a pool of sweet-&-sour sauce. Whether it's kung pao, General Tso's, Mongolian or cashew nut, it's probably here. Fried rice, chow mein, wonton...it's here. Even chow fun. Oh wait, is that where the name comes from? Nah. At $5.99 per pound, it adds up if you're on a carb binge. I tried to load up on Szechuan eggplant, mapo tofu and cauliflower, but I still failed because I scooped up Shanghai noodles, pork fried rice and a few steamed dumplings (photo: http://bit.ly/1M5lnY2). The scale creeped up over $11. I was screwed. At least there's a lot of open tables in the mezzanine area above where you can have a panoramic view of the warming trays (photo: http://bit.ly/1gjZoRz). Are we having fun yet?

FOOD - 2 stars...a lot of stuff to pile on your plate but it's fairly greasy no matter what you get
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...the food is monitored with some frequency and the second floor has tables
SERVICE - 2 stars...couldn't tell ya
TOTAL - 2 stars...like being at an urban Panda Express during a red egg & ginger party...definitely adds up
author: Ed U.

description:
Don't eat here. It's a rip off. You're better off going to a buffet. Most of the items are thickly battered drowning in heavy, heavy "sweet and sour sauce"
The flavor is bland and tastes like every other manufactured Chinese meal no matter what you go. 
I was looking for "comfort food" and I ended up with an empty wallet.
author: Jay N.

description: This place tastes horrible! The food tastes like it's been cooked the day before. Basically your eating leftovers and not the one you want to eat  And you don't get much food for a pound fyi. I'm still shocked this place still exists, but maybe not for long.
author: Nance H.

description: A buffet-style Chinese restaurant with hot plates full of all of your favorite Chinese dishes. It's paid by the pound and they have lots of turnover so the food is always fresh. There is limited seating but most people buy it to go. They also sell beverages of the non-alcoholic type.
author: Aaron W.

description:
After 4 check-ins, I've decided that this is my lunch buffet go to place. Here are just two reasons why: the char siu (BBQ Pork) is fresh, which is very often not the case with other Chinese buffets. Typically other place's BBQ pork can taste off/old and this is 4 times in a row where it is tender, generally lean and very enjoyable.

The greens and string beans are not overdone. they are bright and (in the case of the green beans) still have snap to them.

No I don't expect authentic Shanghai/Hunan/etc.  Chinese food but I've been to my share of sad Chinese buffets that are just meh. There are non-deep-fried versions of dishes or ones where the chicken in not coated in batter. And they have very good stir-fry vegetarian options at the farthest end (away from the door) of the buffet.

I can get as much/little rice/noodles as I want, which bodes better for low carb (yes you will need to contend with corn starch), but I like the wide variety and consistent quality I've found here.

Keep it up China Fun!
author: Glenn H.

description:
Not fun.

There is a woman who, while you are walking past, will make you feel like your looking for something in a dark ally in Bangkok.

Everything looks good but taste horiable. I come at least once a week because it's only $6.00 for lunch but afterwards my tongue is always burning from the salt.

On the upside, only once in the dozens of times I've eaten here have I had food that tasted so bad I was unable to eat it!

Try the fresh green vegetables! I always get the Chinese broccoli.
author: Justin S.

description: The quality of the food here is pretty poor. I decided to stop by later in the day, and the food was room temperature. I'm guessing that it had been sitting there all day uneaten. About halfway through my meal I found a few hairs in the food, and I just stopped eating and left.
author: Tanner L.

description: Don't get anything with "beef".  There is NO way that the meat they are using when they say "beef" is coming from a cow *shudder*.  That being said, this place is not as bad at Lee's.  Some of the food is halfway decent - the veggie stir fries, the fried rice and the kung pao chicken were all a-ok in my book.  Pro-tip: when you get the buffet, you are entitled to a free small soup.  Although, the soup requires an entire packet of soy sauce to be added (and I usually find food to be way too salty) - it's still free so you have to get it. The price here is cheaper than Lee's too - it's about $6 per pound as opposed to other places in the area that charge you something like $11, or whatever amounts to costing you $6 for 3 shreds of lettuce and a quarter of an avocado. I've eaten here twice and have not gotten sick so that's actually pretty good for cheap FiDi eats if you ask me.
author: Emma H.

description: The food is good , price per pound, cheap , and super fast. Just moved into the city and will keep coming back.
author: Jimmy P.

description:
I think the 3 Star rating is SPOT on.
I knew what I was getting myself into when we went here as we just wanted some cheap Chinese food.

It was fine for what it offers in terms of value, but like what other reviewers have mentioned, temperature of the food varied wildly from dish to dish (which can pose a health hazard if food is contaminated) as we were there for dinner.

Thankfully I had no issues.
author: Denis M.

description:
This is one of the dozens of lunch places on Kearny and it's surprisingly good.
There are the usual tables to sit at should you so chose but it's one of the easiest places on Kearny to get in and get out.
The food buffet style self served, what you see is what you get, priced by the pound. A careful eater could make out quite nicely here price wise. I didn't go that route alas as I was quite hungry having missed breakfast. 
I ate everything.
The food is decent if not outstanding-it's fresh, hot and there is a lot of it. The style is more panda express then street stall bejing, with the usual suspects-orange chicken etc. The most authentic items are the veg options.
Cans and bottles for drinks.
author: Steven W.

description:
After just a few visits to this place, I am completely sold. It's priced by weight - $5.99 per pound - which comes out to about what any other Chinese restaurant would cost. But what I like about this place is that you can help yourself. You can have as much or as little as you want. If you want to sample everything, you can. If you just want a little snack, you can just get a little. If you only like sweet and sour pork for the pineapple - like me - you can TOTALLY JUST GET PINEAPPLE. It's amazing.

And it's all super fresh too. Everything looked like it had just been put out. All the condiments are out too, so you don't have to ask for extra hot mustard or chili oil or anything. This place also has a ton of variety. It's quick and delicious.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
Sketchy ass health score but the food is sooo good. 
I live for their eggplant.
author: Cindy Z.

description: Great varieties of food and soup options; friendly staff and very convenient location from major streets. I was Thet between Ling and dinner time so lm not sure how busy it's in general and whether it affects overall service quality.
author: Jay L.

description: Delicious Chinese food. The chicken items were not overly breaded. The establishment was very clean. I came here near closing time and they still had more then enough options.
author: Elizabeth N.

description: Very good self service, pay by the pound Chinese food. The variety was plentiful and the food was pretty dang good. If you are looking for 5-star high quality Chinese cuisine, this is not it, but then again you would most likely not find that in a self service environment. Good food for the price.
author: Terry H.

description:
For this kind of price at a location this central, you've gotta have the right expectations. This buffet serves food made with fresh ingredients, non of that droopy discolored vegetables. There're many premium items you can select to make a tasty meal. Honestly authentic american chinese food with some tasty actual asian/chinese food. The singaporean noodles were seasoned perfectly. They have very well made chinese broccoli. The chicken was so tender. The broccoli beef was also amazing. There is even dim sum. Albeit not made from scratch like at a dim sum restaurant, it's still tasty and fresh. It also only cost $6 for a pound. Their hot and sour soup was a miss. But it's free!
Verdict, if you are looking for a quick and cheap food to grab, china fun is the perfect place. Will definitely revisit.
author: Gong C.

description: Great food, This is an office favorite! Not great on healthy-wise, but so delicious!
author: Raychel C.

description: We were determined to eat chinese in Chinatown...never mind the San Francisco Rice-a-roni treat.   This place was near the main gate and we just wanted something light to go for  simple dinner after an ample cioppino lunch.   Buffet styles so i got several meat/veggie mixes, some noodles, dim sum, veggie egg rolls and sesame balls.   As in most such buffets, every thing had been steamed/heated to a limp mass, but all items were decent, and the per-pound price of $5.99 is hard to beat.   Tables and chairs were available but mostly to-go customers and quick check-out.
author: Mike S.

description:
I'm Chinese and I've definitely had my fair share on dim-sum and fast food restaurants. 

The customer service was actually great. Everyone is super friendly and I felt like it was my aunts who were greeting me when I walked in. 

The atmosphere is average. It has an old fashion hangout feel. The lighting is pretty dim and relies more on the windows. 

The food was terrible. It was either undercooked or over cooked. The broccoli and carrots literally tasted like they were thrown in last minute. I still could taste the rawness of it (I guess it's fine since I do occasionally eat raw vegetables). The fried rice was almost mushy; it was so close to forming a paste like texture. The sweet and sour chicken was a huge miss. When you make sweet and sour chicken, honey walnut shrimp, or anything like that, you dip the meat into a batter and fry it. There was so much batter and barely any chicken. 

I've never tasted prison food but I expect it to be something like that. I really wanted to like this place too! Sorry.

This restaurant charges food by weight ($5-6/pound). Is it worth it? In my opinion, no.
author: Ida H.

description: Fun, and the family loved it.... Vic was in a food coma afterwards. Top - review the offering beforehand
author: Justin T.

description:
I got Salmonella!!!

If I can give this place zero star - i would! - I've passed this place many times during my usual afternoon stroll and I said to myself - this would be a "last resort" kind of place for me. So one rainy day with only a few minutes to spare, I thought i'd give it a try since It was quick and cheap. I got the Singapore style noodles and the Chicken Wings. The food was OK, the chicken wings were soaked and covered in sauce. The flavor and taste was typical. Nothing special. 

Later that night - i started to feel sick. Initially I thought maybe I was coming down with a cold or flu. However, the discomfort became severe as cold sweat, cramping and nausea ensued. When I got a 102 fever I knew it was something serious. I went to the doctors and took some tests. The fever was gone after a day, however, the discomfort from stomach cramps continued. I couldn't eat and i was dehydrated. I realized I've been food poisoned which was later confirmed to be Salmonella. 6 days later and i'm still recovering from it - i was finally able to eat a full meal. I had to miss 2 Holiday Parties because of this. I guess the only good thing to come out of this experience is I lost about 7 lbs :-) 


Next time you go to this place - just be careful.
author: Ted G.

description:
If you are looking to satisfy you craving for quick, Chinese takeout style food, this is the spot. In and out, to go or eat in, this place is easy, casual, and has plenty to choose from. Granted, it all looks and taste roughly the same, but you're not coming here for a 5 star restaurant experience. 

Come here if you want a quick, American Chinese lunch. Pay for food by the pound!
author: James D.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE!!! I signed up to Yelp just to warn people about this place. I swear, I wish I could give this place ZERO stars. Like, if I could give them negative stars, I would!!!

I ran into to this place not too long ago. I went to the place a about twice, and the food was pretty good for the price. Then, on my third visit to China Fun Express, I got some food to go one night. When I opened up the box, the eggplant and garlic sauce smelled funky (like it almost smelled spoiled). So I didn't eat the food and I threw it out, but I was thinking, "It was nighttime, so now I know I can't get food at night." Nonetheless, I wasn't too trusting of the food from that point on. 

I didn't go to the spot for a month--until yesterday. I was super hungry and I needed something small to eat that was cheap (and I didn't want Chipotle).  I got my food around 5pm, so the food should still be fresh (especially since its a buffet). Then, fast forward to 7pm. I started to get some stomach cramps. Within minutes the stomach cramps turned into excruciating pain. I know this was caused by the food I got at this place because the only thing I ate the entire day was a small cup of walnuts and craisins.  Thankfully my roommate walked in a few minutes afterwards and helped me. My roommate was scared I got food poisoning. Long story short, I started puking. Thankfully the pain subsided and I didn't have to go to the emergency room.

But now I'm scared to eat take out food anywhere for a while, and I am forced to eat very little so I don't disturb my body. San Francisco really needs to put health ratings in the widows the way New York City does!! I have no clue how this place is still open.
author: Michelene J.

description:
Terrible....chicken was rubber and couldn't penetrate it with the plastic fork we used.  It was cold and chewy too; the place was empty.

Would never go back.  Don't waste your time.
author: Jesse R.

description:
Despite the tacky looking logo this place isn't half bad. If variety is the spice of life - this place definitely has a lot of life.

This place pleasantly has a perfect or near-perfect health score the last time I checked.
author: Thomas C.

description: Decent Chinese food, good variety, and lots of tables and seats in the upper floor.  Comfort food without making reservations or large crowds.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
I didn't give it 0 stars because:

1) serve yourself, which is awesome
2) you get your food and eat immediately 

But...

It's not that cheap and what I got was not good. Fried rice was below average, chow mein was average, I couldn't even swallow the beef in the broccoli and beef. The general Taos chicken was ok. 

Im an avid American Chinese food fan and this was not at all what I was looking for. If your looking for more traditional Chinese food dishes maybe they are good but I'm not that kind of guy. If your looking to pile your plate with fried rice, chow mein, and orange chicken, you will disappointed.
author: Jacob G.

description:
$5.88 per pound.  

I've walked by a hundred times but never walked in until today when I met several former coworkers for lunch.  

Grab a tray and start piling your food onto a plate.  Be careful with the noodles and rice as it'll weigh your plate down. 

Something for every palate.
author: Shirley N.

description: First time here convenient to my job and was having a craving for greasy Chinese food and it certainly hit the spot. Buffet style and you pay by the pound. I got fried rice , chow mein, broccoli beef, tofu with black mushrooms ( the most delicious) sweet and sour chicken then shrimp dumpling and egg roll and a pot sticker. It was ok I don't know if I would go here again the egg roll and pot sticker were really dried up , sesame chicken good , beef and broccoli- ok sweet and sour chicken pretty good. I think if you go with the attitude it just so so Chinese and don't expect to get great Chinese then you're ok it's simply a convenient place when there's not much choice on a Saturday downtown !
author: lyn m.

description: Cheap, basic, quick Chinese food. Nothing fancy or gourmet but it get the job done.
author: E L.

description:
Ok so I really like this place, against my better judgment... It looks slightly sketchy but hey, I was craving some Chinese food so I decided to take a gamble. I see that it is $5.88 per pound, but a pound of food doesn't really mean anything to me. I fill up my thing for dinner and it's only $4.80! So cheap! So yummy! Not gourmet chinese food by any means but yummy and quenched my craving.

DEFINITELY going back since it's 1.5 blocks from my office.
author: Alexandra W.

description:
I've been hesitant to try this place out but after a co-worker brought back some noodles to share one day, I succumbed and just went for it. 

Guys, I've been there three times this week. But I have my reasons:

1.) I wanted to get a jump start on breaking my New Year's Resolution of eating more moderately and mindfully. (Ironically, my other resolution is to procrastinate less, which, beside in this case, I will fail at miserably.)

2. I like visiting a place a few times before writing a review so I can get an accurate experience. THIS WAS ALL FOR YOU!

3. It hits the spot for greasy food cravings that inevitably come along and it's super affordable.

As usual, my disclaimer is to take it for what it is. This is neither a gourmet, super authentic Chinese place, nor is it the most American Chinese place you'll find and there's probably MSG in the stuff, which totally doesn't make me feel good, but totally is not what I'm thinking about when I want to put their crispy hot wings in my face.  

It is however, consistent and has a wide selection of items. Grab a tray and whatever size container you want to get to it. Multiple options for starch, seafood, chicken, beef, and veggie, along with dumplings, egg rolls, and soup. My faves: The aforementioned hot wings, some crispy shrimp thing that never seems to be labeled, and the green beans. I think it's $5.88/lb. which is great because I need to feel worse about my habits and weighing them seems the way to go. 

Seriously though, everyone here is super nice and the line, if there's ever one, moves quickly. Better than a buffet because you only pay for what you actually choose to take.
author: Suganthi J.

description:
Decent, cheap, seems clean and food looks mostly fresh. I did arrive at 130. so a bit late for the lunch crowd. I did notice (as one Yelper pointed out) that they trays are small although there is a big variety, the potions are small. I thought this was because it was late in the lunch day, but I think it's too keep the food fresher, by less exposure.
Anyway the veggies where fresh, the tofu was good, chicken was tender. The sauce for me was a bit too much and sweet, but overall decent cheap Chinese buffet, probably a bit white-washed.
author: Monica H.

description: Don't understand the complaints . Maybe it is not a prefect restaurant, but pretty cheap and tasty.
author: Ilkin N.

description: Interesting that so many reviews are from people out of town or out of state.  This place is great!  They are super friendly, the food is buffet style, but is fresh and tasty.  They have good sweet and sour chicken and a variety of rice options.  Plus, lunch comes with Soup!  Very good value for the money.
author: Erik P.

description: China Fun Express!! China Fun Express!! Good food, nice location. Everything looks clean. Fantastic place for lunch.
author: Cory M.

description:
Pay-by-the-pound buffet. A filling plate with a can of soda gonna run you 7 to 8 bucks after tax.

Food on the whole is OK. Meats are about Panda Express caliber, the stuff with the sweet sauce is a bit too cloyingly sweet. Veggie dishes are much better, though, and there's a solid 8 or so of them plus a salad bar. 

Gets at least 3 stars because I think it's the only place in the FiDi open on holidays, bailed me out on Thanksgiving Day one year when I was staying down here.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
So there's nothing overtly wrong with this place, you can get decent Chinese here for $5.88 a pound.
That said, the only thing worth getting is the Chinese Style Chicken wings, they are off the chain...
I got 30 egg rolls for a pot luck, they were soggy and tasted like they came out of a Costco package,
Come here when you need a cheap lunch. Don't stay and eat as the place looks grimy.
author: Jack W.

description: We stumbled upon this place after our original choice was closed. They do self serve food by the lbs @ 5.99/lb. The food was average nothing super special. The building is older and the age is showing. The tables are mostly 2 sweaters. I would come back here for a quick bite. The staff was frisky and welcoming.
author: David T.

description: Super close to my office, and will hit the spot for cheap and quick Chinese food. There are a ton of options, and at a little over $5 a pound, it's a steal of a deal. They have tons of stir fry, fried food, vegetables, and even some dim sum options as well. Pretty sure there's msg in some of the food, because it'll make me groggy after awhile, but what do you expect?
author: Annie S.

description: Super cheap and quick. Great for a snack. Went at 11am and the fried rice, chow fun noodles, sesame chicken and General Tso's chicken all tasted fresh and delicious.
author: Phil L.

description:
This place is great if you want quick hot Chinese food. They have a wide variety
of options and they are constantly refreshing the food. I recommend staying away from the egg rolls and steamed buns, they aren't that delicious and they are very heavy. (they charge by the pound here.)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
3 stars = "A-OK"...I'd say that's a fair assessment.

However, if the rating were based on helpfulness in achieving one's daily allotment of vegetables, China Fun would get 5. Really, if not for this place, that section of my food pyramid would be woefully lacking.

Now, don't come here expecting Chinese CUISINE...this is Chinese GRUB. But it's fresh grub, and it tastes pretty good. The staff is all over the trays, constantly checking and refreshing. They have brown rice, which is a big draw for me, and you get free soup if you spend at least $5, which is easy to do, as the price per pound is a little over that.

A few other reviewers noted that the battered and deep-fried items tend to be kind of hard, and that can be true. I do a spoon test-squish before selecting any of those items.

Give China Fun a try next time a craving hits. You just might like it.
author: Valeria R.

description:
I figuratively feel like the oil inside a deep fryer before all of the food at China Fun Express is dumped in. Seriously, what is going on with the fattiness? Expect to feel gross and disgusted after eating the food here. Your stomach will want to jump out and stab you in the eye. I don't even know what that really means. I think I accidentally stole a sweet and sour soup; I wasn't sure if the cashier told me to take one or was just pointing out where it was located. I can't...

Why are you reading reviews on this place? This place should not have such a high rating. People, we are in San Francisco! There is a high Chinese population here; an institution like this is such a slap in the face to authentic chinese cuisine.
author: Tommy C.

description: Very salty. Chow mein and everything in general was very salty and a little rubbery. However, this place IS extremely cheap and I'd go back if I were looking for a cheap bite. Honestly I would prefer Panda Express to this even though China Fun Express has more selection.
author: Elizabeth F.

description: If you're looking for a gourmet meal this is probably isn't your spot. For the price you can't beat the variety or the tastiness of the food. Also the staff is very friendly.
author: Mark D.

description: I work a few blocks away and so far, I've hit this place twice in 2 weeks. First as a trial run and the second time to treat my sister during our lunch break on her birthday today. First time, I just took a little of everything, this time I went all in. Spent $20 between the two of us. including a drink. Its not the best chinese food I've tasted, however, Its really good compared to what I find in the east bay. My favorite thing to get is the China Fun shrimp. Long story short, Its not the best looking place, but If youre in the area, have a few dollars and are craving chines food in the financial district thats NOT panda express, come here!!
author: tiara E.

description:
I will keep this simple:

The Good -- HUGE selection in the buffet, decent prices ($5.88/lb + tax), Kung Pao Chicken, egg rolls, fast and friendly service, vegetarian and soup selections aplenty

The Bad -- pot stickers, General Tso's chicken, sesame chicken, sweet and sour chicken, one employee pestering pedestrians to come in and eat

The Ugly -- little seating (though good for take out), laughable salad bar, broccoli beef, the overwhelming guilt of eating a pound of Chinese food, the shame of bypassing a salad for the same price next door, my breath after eating, my arteries after eating

The food itself is average, but the selection is wide and the price is decent for being in the middle of the Financial District. Probably would come back when craving Chinese, but there are a lot of better (and healthier) options in the area for just a dollar or two more.
author: Jeremy D.

description: This places cheap comparing to other restaurants on Kearny. Price is 5.99/lb, also cheaper than lee's deli ( I had lee's deli one day, beef is bitter!). Food quality is not that bad, when I came in, the new fresh dishes were just came out. Owners and people also greeted on me, and they are very nice! Accept credit card without minimum charge! If you want something quick, Chinese food, cheap, it is a very wise choice!
author: Nina H.

description: Bad food and highly "Americanized".   Cold, bland.   Never again will I go there.  Buffet style of several choices.   Chicken, beef, bean curd, vegetables.  Different fried rices and noodles.   3 types of Dim sum.   Too ad it was all bad tasting.  All was cold.  Dumpling doughy.  Broccoli beef tasteless. Kung Pao not remotely spicy.   Barbecue chicken just so-so.
author: Kim E.

description:
One word to sum up my lunch for today: Greasy.

The variety of dishes is what makes this place eye catching.  And they also have a salad bar if you decide to choose the healthy route after seeing all the greasy dishes.

I love dim sum - so I was glad to be able to add that portion to my meal.  But, as I'm sitting at my desk with my mouth watering over my shrimp dumplings, I take a bite and come to find 2 small pieces of shrimp.  Where's my shrimp dumpling?  I got a mouth full of dumpling - that's unsatisfying!

Anyway, if you are around this area and you are looking for a place that is somewhat similar, try Lee's Deli.  Exactly the same, but better quality.  Chinese food, dim sum, salad bar and they even make sandwiches.
author: Natasha R.

description:
The food here is pretty nice, they have a lot of vegetarian options too.

Just one bad thing, when I was eating my chow main there was a long black hair in it which was nasty. :/ which is why i'm giving 1 star.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Here's the quick and dirty:

The tofu dishes are really good.
The lemon chicken and the sesame chicken dishes were 100x better than the beef dishes.
Fried rice is blah. 
Chow fun is dece. (Decent)
All of the vegetables were a tad overcooked, but dece.
Har gow (shrimp dumpling) is meh.
The decor upstairs is a sight to behold. (Sticky tables/chairs/rainforest paintings included)

However, if they do give free soup for orders over $5, they need to put that up somewhere withing eye view...

Overall, a solid 3.
author: Eunice K.

description:
CFE is surprisingly decent for what is is. Having gone to high school across the street from the Cal campus, I've had more than my fair share of cheap Chinese buffet (bonus tip: "$1 Chinese" is a REALLY bad idea). Luckily, this place is one of the best I've tried. 

They offer an excellent variety of dishes, including a few unexpected items like roast duck or even dim sum. They are also the only place I've found that manages to offer fried dishes that taste fresh. Stuff like sweet & sour pork or sesame chicken always tastes like soggy gelatinous goop at most Chinese buffets. Somehow CFE is able to pull it off.

BONUS STAR FOR GOING GREEN! They've recently ditched all those styrofoam plates and take out trays in favor of recycled cardboard plates and trays!! Yay!
author: Aaron M.

description: Basic but good quality Chinese food. Not too greasy, good selection. Pretty fresh. SUPER FRIENDLY employees. One woman got me a take out container as I was waiting in line. She had a huge smile on her face and was so sweet. I would come back just for her attitude! They also have a great selection of tasty Asian boxed drinks (Vitasoy in various flavors, lychee drink). I'm a fan!
author: Janel T.

description:
The warm, extensive seating was very welcome on this windy, drizzly day. The food itself was merely warm (rather than hot), which is disturbing on a buffet, and of uneven quality. The various chicken items (General Tso's, lemon, sesame, etc) were tasty but the noodles and steamed buns were only fair. 

Food is sold by weight ($5.88/lb) and on orders over $5 you get free soup (fair), white or brown rice, and hot tea. Staff are friendly and I plan to return to more thoroughly explore which items are best.
author: Bill B.

description: Good food, great people :) I love how they only cool a small amount of every dish, so the food never stale, unless you come in around 5pm :p because it's in the financial district, as soon as the office emptied out so does some of the area. But all in all, I like it ^.^ and the people are always nice too, smiles always make anyone's day.
author: Patricia N.

description:
This place is pretty meh (like most Chinese buffet type restaurants). The Hot and Sour Soup is without a doubt the worst that I've ever had. You pay by the pound ($5.88 per pound).

I see no reason for ever coming here.
author: Vivian A.

description:
China Fun Express--I just love the name.  I think I got an MSG reaction the first time I heard of it.  

Working in the FiDi on and off for years, I must've passed this restaurant on Kearny countless times.  But I never gave it a second thought, until a couple of friends mentioned that they enjoyed going there for lunch.  So I figured, it couldn't be that bad.  Despite numerous options in the area, I tend to stick to the same familiar places.  Adding a new lunch place to my list couldn't hurt.    

It is a buffet style/steam table set-up of classic, americanized Chinese cuisine.  What I do enjoy is that they separate their vegetable entrees (which include tofu dishes), making it easier for vegetarians to gravitate to, rather than having to guess which tray is veggie amongst the other meat dishes.  They are also clearly labeled (there is a vegetable dish that has oyster sauce, i.e., not vegetarian).  

Pricing is based per pound. I've been here several times now, and I've managed to keep it down to under $6, yet still have a filling meal.  (And I believe if you spend more than $5, you get free soup.)  There is plenty more seating upstairs.  The trays, seats, and tables, are almost always sticky, so beware, lest you ruin your business casual attire.  

I haven't gotten an adverse reaction to MSG yet, so China Fun is a-ok in my book.
author: Marsha Z.

description: My favorite go-to place for Chinese buffet food.  Yes, most of the time I feel guilty after I eat it, but I'm pretty sure they put crack in their dishes because I get a craving for it from time to time that nothing else will satisfy.  Yes, it's laden with oil, sugar, and salt.  What do you expect?  However, the dishes are well-prepared and the food is replaced frequently.  The flavors are vibrant and the selection is impressive.  The folks who work there are quite nice, and--a biggie for me--look at their Dept. of Public Health score:  100%.  That earns them the fifth star, in my book.
author: Earline A.

description:
I love this place, and honestly don't understand the complaints.  It's a very inexpensive steam table place, where food is cooked small batches, and refilled frequently. You can pick and choose - pick wisely, buy rice in a separate bowl, and you can have a great cheap meal.  Really friendly people work here, and if your favorite has run out, ask and they will make more.
also, lots of vegetarian options.
author: Beth K.

description:
This is where I go when I can splurge (calories) on greasy Chinese food! Don't go to Lee's for their hot deli if you can make it here. They offer plenty ot Panda Express like choices and most food are hot and doesn't seem like it's been sitting under the heat lamp too long. 

Again...come here only if you plan on having a heavy greasy Chinese food lunch.
author: Maggie C.

description: The place is called China Fun Express. It is exactly what you're picturing right now. Buffet full of Chinese food, along with some fruits and vegetables, sold by the pound to those who work on Kearny corridor. The food is decent, more utilitarian than epicurean, but gets the job done. If you work downtown and you're peckish, but watching cash and not too picky, give this a shot.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I had a great lunch here!!  I took a sample of everything and couldn't find a single thing I didn't want to devour. 

Sesame chicken, the egg roll, and the broccoli beef were probably my favorites.
author: M.B. J.

description:
=China Fun Express=

$5.88 for a pound of food! Any weight over, you pay the extra! Not a bad concept but... Most of the food will generally weigh more than a pound so you kind of get the end of the stick here. However, the food is actually really damn good. I happened to hit over $10 bucks and I got a free bowl of soup. I ended up getting over 6 items. haha. Like a mini buffet for me.

-Fried Chicken (Really good)
-Braised String Beans (Needs more flavor)
-Chow Mein (Tasty)
-General Cao Chicken (Not bad)
-Hot and sour soap (Too bland)
-Beef and Brocolli (Tender meat)
author: Christopher J.

description:
China Fun Express is a self serve Chinese food buffet. They charge about 5.80 something a pound, which comes out to be more expensive than your average Chinese restaurant. They have a good variety of Chinese food ranging from dim sum stuff to roast duck. 

The right side of the restaurant has the main buffet. Closest to the door has chow mien and rice. Then comes chicken dishes, pork dishes, beef dishes. Next is some misc stuff like dim sum and finally the veggie stuff is way at the end of the buffet table. The left side of the restaurant seems to have food and desserts. Sauces and stuff are kept at the counter in the back of the restaurant.

The quality of the food is alright quality. It's your average tasting Chinese food so there's nothing amazing about this place's Chinese food.
author: Steven B.

description: Some of the best, easiest takeout in the area.  Cheaper than some of the competition down on Market street and better, too.  For bonus points, get take out and go up to the rooftop garden on top of the Crocker Galleria.  No tables, but it's quiet and there are several park benches with shade.
author: Mandell D.

description:
Let me just say this at front, I like this place. I've been working in Fidi for last um mm what , 5-6 month now?? When i commute, i pass this restaurant every morning. Yet, last Friday, when i get off work. i went in there for the first time. I kinda had an idea that it was buffet table in there, but i didn't know it was that big. Since i am a portly young male, i luv buffet, and no one better hurry me in a buffet line. Due to my medical reason, I've been watching my Carbs lately. So i skip my favorite fried rice, chow mein ,AND chow fun. there was sweet n sour chicken( Three different types). And there was my Dim Sum. That's it, When i saw all those HarGaw, Shumai, and Rice noodles. I was nothing shy about it. And top of it, they open until 8 at evening. 

I will definitely go back there and try fried rice next time.
author: Danny P.

description:
If you want a quick and delicious bite, this is the place to go. They are constantly putting out fresh food and they are very friendly. The food is is healthier than most places and has less oil and no msg. 

They are a bargain price as well. I usually spend between $3 (cheap I know) and $5 when I grab the small container, including rice!
author: Erran A.

description:
I'm chinese and I approve of this place.

You must exercise self-control or you'll end up paying $13 for lunch!
author: Rong H.

description:
They have a secret thing here -- spicy fried chicken wings. They're in the back row of the steam table and they only make about 1/2 dozen at a time. 

As if tossing them in chili oil and red chili flakes isn't enough, they also liberally apply jalapeno chunks. I'm slowly working my way up from being able to eat two of these without practically dying, to chomping down 3. It's slow going. They taste so good you have to wolf them down, but then once the actual effect hits you you have to run for the nearest napkin and water source. Too bad i can't crack a beer at my desk. Too bad, indeed.

 They use the non-drumette part of the wing, but the wing parts they get seem to be very meaty, so all is well.
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
I started working nearby and have been looking for a good steam-table place. This is it.

Just stopped by for lunch and it was all very hot, fresh and good. Yes...it's "Americanized", but that's what I was looking for. I'm fine with that.

Turns out that I have been coming here for many years and didn't know it...how, you ask? Well...during the Chinese New Year Parade, when I and 500 billion of my closest friends descend on Kearny to see the parade as it turns the corner, food is hard to come by. And I have braved the crowds many times to go here and load up with a couple of large plates full of food. I have never been disappointed with the freshness. A few years back, I brought the extended family, parked our butts on Kearny and headed over to China Fun Express. $25 later, all 10 of us had full bellies. Looking forward to that again this year.
author: Scot B.

description:
Maybe I shouldn't brag about this, but if I checked-in every time I ate here, I'd definitely be the queen of Fun!

I've worked in the immediate area for almost two years now and spent half that amount of time searching for a good Chinese food lunch spot. With Chinatown right up the hill, you'd think I'd have had no problem, but it was really rough.

Now what was it exactly that prevented me from giving this place even a second glance for nearly a year when I work right across the street? Was it the yellow and purple signage with the smiley faces? Or perhaps it was the name "China Fun"... Or might it have been the slogan "It's fast...and it's fun!"?

Whatever it was, don't let yourself make the same presumptions I did.

The food is cheap for the FiDi - I think around $5-and-change per pound. Though some say the quality is sub-par, suggesting it's too oily, or too battered, or whatever, when you compare it to the hot food section at Lee's (which I think is the most similar in terms of selection, location and price), it's no contest- Fun all the way!

My faves are the beef broccoli, the garlic eggplant, the BBQ pork and the various orange chicken-like dishes (there are a few slightly different options). I've had a few noodle dishes that didn't blow my mind, but then again, I've never really been a noodle girl. 

I love that you get free soup with every meal AND you get to choose between egg drop and hot-and-sour! Fancy.

Like Lee's, I've never left this place having spent more than $10. More than $10 a day is another story... I admit that sometimes Fun happens at both lunch and dinner... Sorry for partying.
author: Marie A.

description: The staff is SO FRIENDLY and nice...but this food gets more & more salty. Fat doesn't bother me as much as the weird salt overload afterward.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
The food is cheap and decent for buffet style Chinese food -- it tastes better than Lee's deli Chinese food. But remember it's Americanized Chinese food -- expect sweet sweet sauce and grease.

Lots of choices and respectable veggie options in the back. Buy over $5 worth of food and you get free soup (egg drop or hot n sour). 

It's my go-to fast food option when I don't feel like settling on 1 dish.
author: Su K.

description:
Certainly not bad. The best that I've had in the area and it's definitely better than Lee's. 

On the cool side, you can get a bit of this and that if you just want a snack.

On the uncool side, you can end of paying $8 for a tray of veggies if you don't watch yourself.
author: Kiristen R.

description: Basically a Chinese cafeteria and surely unhealthy. BUT Tasty, cheap, fast, better than you'd expect. That's the whole deal here.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This place is actually pretty okay for being fast-food Chinese. Their lunch buffet has a really interesting pricing model - you pay for you what you eat (they weigh your food)!

As far as the food itself... nothing too out of the ordinary and definitely not the healthiest, but it does seem to have a bit of a more authentic taste than most places around. I wouldn't mind going back every once in a while. :)
author: Sweta A.

description:
I like this take-out format. You can choose exactly what you want and how much of it. As a result, you can have a bite of everything if you wanted.

One word of caution as with any buffet is to really examine the food. You should prod fried stuff with the tongs to make sure it's still crispy. If a dish looks dried out, it's likely dried out.

I found their fried rice quality to be better than comparable chinese places in the neighborhood. The fried rice actually had pieces of barbecue pork, yum. They actually had dishes that were spicy which hit my greasy salty spicy craving today.
author: Clodel G.

description:
Not bad, in my humble opinion!

Why? Because it allows you to cherry-pick everything. You want some mushrooms but you don't want any beef? No problem!

You want a really greasy bun covered in sesame seeds and filled with beany stuff? Score!

How about some jello? I hope you like the red kind. MMM. They even have lichees, and you can pay with your card. The pricing is quite reasonable.

I can spend about $6.50 and be quite satisfied with my lunch. I just have to make sure I don't throw the empty container away under my desk at work, because smelling that stuff for the rest of the day afterward makes me wanna barf.
author: Heidi G.

description:
I don't usually like buffet style restaurants, but China Fun Express is actually pretty darn good. If you need a quick bite this is a great place to try. 

The food tasted great. I don't usually eat meat, but the sesame chicken was savory. Almost everything on my plate tasted fresh, and I noticed the nice lady bringing out freshly cooked items as I sat to enjoy my food. For $6 bucks you can eat enough to last you through out the day... I will be back! 


Also, the customer service is great! The man and woman working made sure to tell me hello & happy new year as I was leaving.
author: Shel Z.

description:
This is a great place for quick and ready-to-go chinese food. Try to go during lunch because i believe this is when you have more options as well as it the most fresh. 

Its cheap and it taste good!!!
author: Cnn F.

description:
So it's about $5.50 a pound of food.  There is NOTHING else open around.  There's "FUN" in the title for crying out loud...why wouldn't we.  So in we went.  $30 later...yes, I spent $30 at a hole in the wall - I could reserved my leftovers to someone else.  It was good but it was FILLING.

I don't recommend the fried "wings" & that is a huge non-recommendation considering fried chicken is my favorite food.

I really liked the beef & broccoli.  Also, despite how unnecessary it is to have 3 different fried rices, I had fun trying all of them.  Next time, if I find myself in the Financial District, up north, on a Sunday before noon - I will definitely come back for JUST the fried rice(s) and beef & broccoli...maybe 1 or 2 pieces of orange chicken as well.  :D
author: Lilani E.

description:
From outside, it looks like a really ghetto chinese fast food joint. I came in hoping the food doesn't look dried up & old...but everything looked pretty good.

I decided to try this place out cuz i was HELLA craving me some dim sum and i was seriously really pissed off that i couldnt find any places in the fidi area on a SUNDAY. grrr...is it that time of the month? Possibly.           :(         :)          :\ 

I like how i'm allowed to choose whatever items i want & they can just charge me by the pound. The lady was really nice & friendly.

fatty fat fatttt :)
author: Rosalynn D.

description: For a quick and dirty buffet, it's really good. They charge by the pound, so be careful loading up on heavy things like rice.
author: Andrew L.

description:
One of the few places open on Sunday on Kearny, I decided to eat lunch here after remembering some good reviews about it on Yelp.  While the restaurant is pretty clean and the proprietor was good about keeping the buffet items fresh, I didn't particularly enjoy my meal.

I decided to get some chow fun, braised tofu and vegetables, and some General Tso's chicken.  The chow fun tasted like it had sat there for a while- the noodles were limp and slightly mushy.  The braised tofu and vegetables were probably the best tasting item- the tofu was soft, while the zucchini and broccoli still had some crunch left to them.  The General Tso's chicken were an abomination- while they looked fresh on the steam table, they were actually more breading than chicken and the breading was chewy rather than crunchy.  

Overall, China Fun Express was a good place to get a fast, if mediocre meal.  It is one of the few places open on Sundays in this part of town, so I may be back if I was really craving Chinese, but its almost easier to head over to the Westfield and get some Panda Express instead.
author: Angela H.

description:
Wow.  Worst Chinese food, ever.  And let me qualify that statement with the fact that I lived in Mexico, and Mexican Chinese food outcompetes China Fun.

I was wowed by the cleanliness and selection of entrees available.  Definitely a clean place, and veg friendly.  But since I'm a meat-lover, I attacked at a variety of meat dishes.

Green beans and beef: Flavorless, but not disgusting.

Eggplant: In their lighting, I didn't notice the radioactive green color it had.  I have never had to spit out food in my life, until China Fun.

Chicken wings: Pretty much baked wings smothered in Asian hot sauce.

"Special" shrimp: I didn't taste any real shrimp meat, just the crunchy tail surrounded by a rock-hard coat of dough.

Ugh.  That pretty much sums it up.  Ugh.
author: Francis L.

description: Even though this place definitely isn't a winner in the "aesthetics" category, the food is tasty and inexpensive. They have many different serving containers you can choose from--plates and to-go containers of all sizes. They have soup in the back which you can get for free if your meal costs $5, but even if it doesn't they're nice enough to let you have some anyway. They price by weight, so if you load up on dense meats, you're probably gonna have to pay a little bit more. It's worth it though.
author: Brittany L.

description:
I like china fun. It ranks high on my cheap chinese-ish food list.

I only go during lunch-ish, however, when I know the food is in good rotation. And usually get the fried-things-in-sauce like the General Tso, Lemon Shirmp, and lemon chicken with rice, with some vegetables to cut down my guilt at eating nothing but fried food. It is always crunchy when I go and not soggy, which I dislike. I've had the soup a couple times and it is a bit oily. The ladies who work there are always really nice too.

And it usually rings under 5$, unless I'm really hungry, then it's usually 8$. I like having lots of variety for little money. :D

I love greasy chinese food.
author: Regina L.

description:
China Fun Express pretty much lives up to its name--unless you're expecting a locomotive adventure with the Ni Hao Kai-Lan characters.

Luckily, I set my expectations pretty low. 

The food is cheap, but average price for Chinese fast food (and this place is just a few blocks away from China Town). However, being able to pick out exactly what you want in the exact amount that you want is great, and brings my rating up to three stars. 

Foodwise, this place would get 2 stars. Their sesame chicken and sesame rolls were both pretty good, but their lemon chicken and fried rice were weak, and their chow mein tasted suspiciously of top ramen. I'd only go back if I really needed a sesame fix.
author: S S.

description:
I should know by now...a pound of Chinese food just isn't that filling (but it sho' is good!).

This place is quick, not too expensive, and seems very clean. The food is refreshed often during the lunch hour, so it is hot and not stale. 

In a land of really expensive lunches, I like a place where I can control the costs if I want.
author: Annie F.

description:
normally, i load up on their fried rice, mixed with their chili fried rice, for dinner takeout at work.  i haven't tried many of their other items, but they do look decent and fresh.. 

they charge something like $5.88 a pound, pretty pricey. comes out to about 20-25% more than what you pay for at panda express, but when you're low on options in the area (chipotle, mcd's, subway)...
author: Ethan L.

description:
As in any buffet situation, I only take what looks brand-new...avoid too much rice, and practice portion control, because it's sooooo easy to take too much of any of these sweet glazed foods...mmmmmmmm.....sweet glazed foods....

A great spot if you are HONG---GREE, and if you've been a good boy (or girl) all week.
author: Randy F.

description: I had a great lunch. I was looking for a quick lunch and felt like Chinese. The Chinese place near my job is very cheap and though I have never eaten there I have had my concerns. Today I opted for China Fun since it brags to be the best. That was great. The Chow Mein was delicious. Both Sweet and Sour and Kung Pao melted in my mouth and filled with flavor. The vegetables were cooked very well. The two egg rolls were some of the best I remember having. I cannot say was expensive for $8 including soda. They sell by weight. That was a great experience and next time I think of China Fun I will remember the food very well and not cost. Forget a quick cheap lunch and try a quick but great lunch at China Fun Express.
author: Cush D.

description:
After two fairly satisfactory visits to this self-styled fun restaraunt, I have to say that the scrolls look favorably upon it.

Imagine free hot & sour soup for spending a measley $5 on a Chinese buffet.  Imagine a decent selection of moderately flavorful food.  Imagine me going to this place... probably once every week or so.  Imagination is the stuff of Legend, and the scrolls doth decree.
author: critical Francis ..

description:
I think that like pizza, Chinese can never really be bad.  This place just isn't good Chinese.  It's acceptable though.  

Imagine a self serve Panda Express then minus 20% for quality.  Does that tell you enough about the place?  

It's a smorgasbord of food.  Anything that you have ever imagined that is Chinese is offered here: chow mien, chow fun, fried rice, potstickers, dim sum, Mongolian beef, kung pao chicken, dim sum, shrimp, sweet and sour chicken, etc.  All in all, I think they offered about 20 plus different dishes.  I feel sorry for the gut who makes all the freakin' food.

So it wasn't the best I've ever had.  But what do you expect for self serve buffet?  It's Panda Express but a little worse.  

Not the cleansest but not filthy either. Typical hole in the wall.  

For the two of us, it was $24.  It is weighed by the pound. Damn are we pigs.  

I still would come back here if there were no other options.
author: Denise B.

description:
Let me assure that you this place is not as fun as it sounds. It is however decent food for an even better price. 

It's a pay by the pound buffet which plenty of selection, plus free soup with your meal. There's seating both downstairs and upstairs; I've never had trouble finding a table. 

It may not be the best or the funnest Chinese food in the area, but it's fast, decent & cheaper than most other restaurants in the area.
author: Justin B.

description: If you are  starving and no other place to go, then try this. Otherwise, i don't recommend to you. This is sold by weight and the food are greasy,deep fried and salty.
author: Ying X.

description: This buffet place that won't disappoint in the FIDI area.  Food is freshly prepared.  They have a good array of meats and veggies dishes.   I really enjoy their ginger/scallion fish option.   Their brown rice is cooked perfectly.   The food isn't overly greasy, and you have the option not to choose them.   When I'm craving for chinese food this is the place to go to.
author: pengrin ..

description:
FUN!!!!!  So fun.
Alotta fun and alotta phun, chow phun that is!
Actually, no more fun than your typical Chinese buffet, but the wallpaper is kind of fun-ny.
Very greasy, tasty, good variety, free soup and smiles.
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description:
They should just change their name to Chinese Food by the Pound.

Currently charging just under $5 per pound. Good place to go if you are indecisive about what to order or if you want a little bit of this and that.

What I like is that brown rice is available. Usually the cashier will ask you, "Free soup foh you?" You can skip it. Soup tastes like library paste. They also have a western "salad bar" selection, but you can skip that, too. The main entrees aren't too bad. Mediocre food but it's cheap and fast for a grab 'n' go lunch.
author: Trixie J.

description:
I eat here when I'm low on money but starving. I bought 4 HUGE eggrolls for like 3 bucks. 

It tasted SOOO GOOD with the sweet and sour sauce, but of cource, I could taste all the lard...which is kinda nasty. =/ 

If you're eating lunch here, like a full plate, I recommend skipping dinner because of all the calories...
author: Sophia G.

description:
Typical fast food, Chinese style, except you get free soup if it's more than 5 bucks. Usually you grease up an engine and it helps run smoother, with this it makes you fall asleep fast and leaves some not so great after taste :(

Also, I filled up the plastic box like I did at Lee's and it was like 10 dollars! Looks like it was actually more expensive?!
author: T L.

description: I come here because it's close to work. I like that they have every type of chinese chicken dish, and multiple beef dishes as well. You pay by the pound and can choose just how much of everything you want. They also have a separate vegetarian section. Not sure if they use MSG but i don't get the headache I normally get when eating MSG.
author: vishal k.

description:
I'd rather not eat, than to come here again. Seriously. I work just half a block down the street and would have loved the convenience of this place, but every time I buy food here, I regret it.

It's cheap, but all Chinese food is pretty cheap. Plus, you can definitely get better quality just about anywhere. The buffet style food sits underneath heatlamps all day, and is saturated with msg and oil. Ugh.
author: Ava C.

description:
For the price this place is great.  They have a good selection if you go during lunch and it beats the heck out of Lee's (which sucks).  I liked the food a tad better than B&M on 2nd because they had a better selection and I got to pick how much of each item I wanted.  

I went to both places and got the same items.  Some were better at one place or the other but overall I gave china fun higher marks for taste.   

I like the fact that at China Fun I can pick how much of what I want and I am not subject to the whim of the lady behind the counter at B&M.  I eat a healthy lunch and was able to be full for under $10.  I filled a to go box and was very satisifed with what I got.

I'd really like to give them 3.5 stars.  I'd return.  The food for the price was better than ok but not good enough to make me a fan.
author: Mark T.

description: I stop by here sometimes on my way back to work after going to the gym on my lunch break.  The food is always hot and abundant.  They are always restocking the food so you never have to worry about the food being old.  I haven't tried there salad/fruit buffet side yet but it always looks fresh when I'm there.  They have different types of fried rice and noodles and plenty of selection of meat, vegetarian, and even dim sum.  Next time when its not so hot...I'll try the hot and sour soup.  The service is great here too...really friendly.
author: Minhphuc T.

description:
It may be the time of day I went, but i was so hungry.  Just got checked in at my hotel, 6 PM on a Sunday,  and I was starving.  I saw this place from my window, so I decided to get a bite to eat.  There was maybe 12 different dishes.  It looked like closing time at a Chinese buffet.  Everything I got was cold.  It was flavorful though.

It was edible, but I wouldn't go back for dinner.  it must be more of a lunch type of place.
author: David S.

description:
Not too bad Chinese restaurant, where you can choose your own. Like others have said, its buffet style, and only go during lunch, because the selection and temperature sways a lot outside of that.

There's nothing terribly unique here. Their business card says "Gourmet Chinese Food" which is a big lie. However, you come for the $6 a pound buffet, and the variety of selection of rice, noodles and meats. I had a little bit of everything;
- fried rice = very good
- Singapore curried noodles - pretty average
- General Tso's chicken - good
- Sweet & Sour Prawns - awesome
- BBQ Pork - pretty average

$7.80 for a box, thank you very much!
author: Joseph T.

description: The white fish steamed in green onion and ginger is good! Also, a huge vegetarian section in the back.  Not bad for a place called China Fun Express.  Right?
author: Wakako U.

description: Quick, convenient, and not bad, at all.  I got chili fried rice, which was had quite a bit of hotness, which I liked.  It was kind of greasy.  Also, lots of vegetables, such as eggplant, mustard greens, sauteed w/garlic, green beans, and a good variety of tofu dishes.  I peaked at the salad bar, and was pleased to see lichee and strawberries...maybe I'll get that next time. I paid 9.00 for a full plate of food, but not heaping.  I think it's like 5.00 lb.
author: Marvella W.

description:
A thirty-foot long buffet table that begins near the entrance catches your attention as you're walking down Kearny Street, while a visible pricing of $5.38 per pound ( 2-28-07...prices subject to change) ropes you in.  Before you know it, the setup has you grabbing one of those cafeteria-style plastic trays, then sliding it down the  line of chaffing dishes and greedily heaping spoonful upon spoonful of oily proteins and carbohydrates into a styrofoam take-out tray.

Sound like fun?  IT IS!!!  But the party's over the minute you get to the cash register.  Soon thereafter, big eaters find out that a pound of Chinese food isn't quite as big as they thought it was.  For reference, the standard Glenpak 3-compartment styrofoam tray with hinged lid weighs in at around 1.82lbs when stuffed to the gills with Chow fun, fried rice, pot-stickers, and broccoli-beef.  The first shock hits when the cute girl behind the cash register beams at you with those big brown eyes, and utters your amount-due through a perfectly charming smile.  It's almost always more expensive than you you expected, but at this point the girl with the charming smile might as well be a bandit holding a loaded .38 to your head.  You can't go back and scoop food back into the trays, and you'd feel like an ass if you complained....so you wind up shelling out somewhere around ten bucks (drink included), and heading off to a table.

The second shock?  You dig into that huge assortment of not-so-cheap Chinese food, and come to the shocking realization that it's *all* incredibly bland.  On my 2-28-07 visit, the Broccoli Beef was OK, though notably long on the Broccoli and short on the beef.  The pot-stickers were borderline-acceptable, and the Chow-Fun, though not dried out, was severely lacking in taste.  Worst of all?  The fried rice was among the blandest I'd ever encountered.  My inner weight-watcher told me to ditch the tray and cut my losses....but my conscious cheapskate howled in protest at the notion of tossing out anything edible that cost me the better part of a twenty-spot.

People had warned me that I wouldn't like this place....but I came here anyway.  If you spend much time on Keary Street, that seemingly endless line of steam trays with the per-pound pricing will probably suck you in too.  Go ahead...bite the bullet....have lunch at China Fun Express.  Just remember...if you wind up disappointed, I told you so....OK?
author: Mike W.

description: I doubt very much that the proprietors of this buffet-style, fast Chinese food restaurant would appreciate knowing that me and my colleagues refer to it as the "House of Hoo-Hoo" amongst ourselves, but they do provide very edible, consistent chow via pay-per-pound. FYI -- the Pork Fried Rice is really flavorful, and they're always super-friendly. And the upstairs dining mezzanine means it's not strictly take-away. Now, your waistline probably won't appreciate you eating here too often, but it's a decent, quick cure for the occasional craving.
author: Gregor G.

description: Yummy yummy food! So many racists posting on here
author: Johnny N.

description: This place sucks. It is hands down the worst chinese food I"ve ever had. I passed it the other day thinking that cheap chinese food by the pound might be alright. Around me everybody looked dejected by the fact that they had decided to eat here too. When I got my shrimp and chicken, I was convinced I was eating fried dough, and wasnt sure there was any meat. NEedless to say chinese food by the pound is not really all that it's cracked up to be.
author: Srinivas R.

description: In general I'm always a little bit skeptical of any restaurant with the word "fun" in its name.  What's so fun about a Chinese food buffet that sells food for $4.98 a pound?  Sure it's inexpensive, but fun? Come on, Chuck E. Cheese's is fun.  Chuck E. Cheese's has a 6 foot tall rat walking around giving out balloons and hugs, and slides that drop you into a ball pit that smells like feet and is probably full of pink eye and lice.  That shit is fun.  I gotta tell you China Fun Express, you should either change your name or put some god damn slides in your restaurant.
author: Broke-Ass Stuart S.

description: Strange but useful Chinese by-the-pound buffet. You can even get bits of select dim sum (shrimp dumplings, potstickers). Reasonable quality. Brown rice! Seemingly unusual and nice. I also like to grab a few extra packets of chili sauce for other take-out lunches from other places. When you don't know what else to eat.
author: Tara M.

description:
For a buffet style Chinese fast food place, it actually wasn't bad.  The name of the place was a bit cheezy and the price that you pay for ($5.58/lb) wasn't very "FUN", however the food exceeded my expectations.

I've tried Lee's Deli and  New Asia Asian Cuisine (at Crocker Galleria) and both left me disappointed and dissatisfied.  Although Lee's Deli has more variety, China Fun Express has better quality and the taste is closer to real Chinese food rather than your typical Panda Express. 

I ordered the broccoli beef with sweet and sour pork and spicy hot fried rice (now THAT'S something you don't see everyday).  The sweet and sour pork had the bright reddish-orange glazed sauce that wasn't hard and the fried rice made me think of the Korean kimchi fried rice.  As for the broccoli beef, I say you can pass on that one.  Too much sauce soaked the broccoli resulting in soggy veggies.  I also wanted to try their chicken corn soup but didn't want to overspend on lunch.      

All in all, people should give this place a chance.  It's clean and decent.  Don't have super high expectations as if you were going to other Chinese restaurants.  Keep you expectations to a minimum when it comes to fast Chinese food.  You'll enjoy more out of it.
author: Esther L.

description:
as my colleague likes to say: no false advertising here.

china - they're from china (well, i heard taiwanese in the kitchen and they spoke mandarin with taiwanese accents so i guess some may say they're of the "china" persuasion)

fun - it's fun to pick out the 30+ items on the hot buffet table. well, HE thinks it's fun. i think it's a no brainer, but that wouldn't make for a very appetizing restaurant name. i guess it's fun trying to jaywalk from my office building across the street on kearny and avoid becoming midday fi-di roadkill.

express - it's fast chinese food. everything is laid out and clean. turnover of each dish is consistent. 

not necessarily the most amazing chinese fast food buffet or even a good one. but hey, then they'd be called "good china fun express."
author: May T.

description: Don't be fooled by the name, it's not that fun.  I think of this as the mc donalds of chinese food.  I know it's shit, but i go back because it's fast and cheap.  The woman at the register is just a little too appreciative and says thank you to everything... Sorry I just don't feel right saying "you're welcome" for taking more soy sauce than I intend to eat.
author: Caleb D.

description:
i love this little chinese buffet.  it's not exactly gourmet, certainly not organic, nor unique cuisine, but it hits the spot.  it's chinese comfort food  - most of it is probably not very healthy, but i trick myself into believing that the steamed ginger fish is sort of a healhy option.  it's really tasty too!  they often have steamed or sauteed green veggies like broccoli, green beens, broccoli rabe and they have a fruit bar which makes for a nice dessert.
best thing is, it's cheap -i can always get out of there satisfied for under $5 and that includes a complimentary cup of soup.
author: Mary C.

description: China Fun Express has a weird name, and a large selection of common Chinese foods like fried rice, curry chicken, chow mein, chow fun, and even some dim sum stuff. None of it is particularly good, but then again, it's cheap, fast and not particularly bad either.  They weigh your food, and charge something like $6 per pound. If you need a quick place to go for lunch, you could definitely do worse.
author: Eric W.

description:
3 1/2 really.  pretty good for a chinese buffet.  your basic selections and then some.  they have a vegetarian section too, and it was tasty.
reasonably priced per pound i suppose, but when i sat down to eat it, the food was really cold.
author: Monk R.

description: This is one of my financial district lunch staples.  Pay by the pound can be a blessing especially for people with small appetites like myself, so first it has that going for it.  Even if you eat more, though, the price is very fair.  The selection is great, and I think they've gotten better about refilling the bins since some of the earlier reviews here b/c they're all always full when I go.  Very tasty and fresh food, especially all the vegetarian dishes.
author: Carolyn B.

description: This is a buffet-style chinese place that serves an array of familiar chinese food dishes with a pretty strong vegetarian section. It's a little over $5 a pound here so you can get a substantial portion for $5-6. The food is pretty good considering the price! My only complaint is that the restaurant itself is a bit grimy and greasy. All the trays are sticky. Ew.
author: Kevan M.

description:
This is a buy-by-weight store. Good selection. Yummy tofu actually! Food stays hot. Lines moves pretty quickly.

No parking. Don't even try.

Decor is pretty atrocious. Just seems dirty.
author: O. K.
